datafield.subfield: Asymptotic behavior for a generalized Domany–Kinzel model

We consider a version of directed bond percolation on the square lattice such that horizontal edges are directed rightward with probabilities one, and vertical edges are directed upward with probabilities p (1), p (2) alternatively in even rows and probabilities p (2), p (1) alternatively in odd rows, where ${{p}_{1}}\in \left[0,1\right)$ , ${{p}_{2}}\in \left[0,1\right)$ , but ${{p}_{1}}\vee {{p}_{2}}>0$ . Let $\tau (M,N)$ be the probability that there is at least one connected-directed path of occupied edges from (0, 0) to (M,N). Defining the aspect ratio $\alpha =M/N$ , we show that there is a critical value ${{\alpha}_{c}}=\left(2-{{p}_{1}}-{{p}_{2}}\right)/\left(\,{{p}_{1}}+{{p}_{2}}\right)$ such that as $N\to \infty $ , $\tau (M,N)$ is 1, 0 and 1/2 for $\alpha >{{\alpha}_{c}}$ , $\alpha <{{\alpha}_{c}}$ and $\alpha ={{\alpha}_{c}}$ , respectively. In particular, the model reduces to the square lattice with uniform vertical probability when ${{p}_{1}}={{p}_{2}}$ [1], and the model reduces to the honeycomb lattice when one of p (1) and p (2) is equal to 0. We study how the critical value ${{\alpha}_{c}}$ changes between the square lattice and the honeycomb lattice as bricks. In this article, we investigate the rate of convergence of $\tau (M,N)$ and the asymptotic behavior of $\tau \left(M_{N}^{-},N\right)$ and $\tau \left(M_{N}^{+},N\right)$ , where $M_{N}^{-}/N\uparrow {{\alpha}_{c}}$ and $M_{N}^{+}/N\downarrow {{\alpha}_{c}}$ as $N\uparrow \infty $ .

The model reduces to the Domany-Kinzel model on the square lattice when {{p}_{1}}={{p}_{2}}=p and q = 1 - p, i.e. c = 0 and b = 2pq (see [, 10: #jstataa4abdbib010]). Equation (, 1.3: #jstataa4abdeqn003) leads to {{\alpha}_{c}}=q/p and (, 2.4: #jstataa4abdeqn008) leads to {{t}_{\alpha}}=\frac{\alpha}{q(\alpha +1)}. According to (, 2.3: #jstataa4abdeqn007), I(\alpha ) can be simplified as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} I(\alpha )=\alpha \ln \left(\frac{\alpha}{q(1+\alpha )}\right)-\ln \left(p(1+\alpha )\right)\quad \text{for}~\text{the}~\text{square}~\text{lattice}. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 2.5 } \end{equation*}

The model reduces to the Domany-Kinzel model on the honeycomb lattice as bricks when b = p2 = c with p1 = 0 or b = p1 = -c with p2 = 0 (see [, 11: #jstataa4abdbib011]). Consider either {{p}_{1}}=0,\,{{p}_{2}}=p or {{p}_{1}}=p,\,{{p}_{2}}=0, and let q = 1 - p with \alpha >1. (, 1.3: #jstataa4abdeqn003) leads to {{\alpha}_{c}}=(q+1)/p and (, 2.4: #jstataa4abdeqn008) leads to {{t}_{\alpha}}=\sqrt{\frac{\alpha -1}{q(\alpha +1)}}. According to (, 2.3: #jstataa4abdeqn007), I(\alpha ) can be simplified as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\begin{array}{*{35}{l}} I(\alpha )=\left(\frac{\alpha -1}{2}\right)\ln \left(\frac{\alpha -1}{q(\alpha +1)}\right)-\ln \left(\frac{p(\alpha +1)}{2}\right)\quad \text{for}~\text{the}~\text{honeycomb}~\text{lattice}. \end{array}\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 2.6 } \end{equation*}

Our result shows that \tau \left({{N}_{\alpha}},N\right) with \alpha <{{\alpha}_{c}} and 1-\tau \left({{N}_{\alpha}},N\right) with \alpha >{{\alpha}_{c}} both decay exponentially to zero. Furthermore, we obtain the critical exponent \nu =2 and B=\frac{1}{2{{\sigma}^{2}}} in (, 1.2: #jstataa4abdeqn002) for \alpha <{{\alpha}_{c}}

The case (1) with {{p}_{1}}{{p}_{2}}c=0 includes both the Domany-Kinzel model on the square lattice and the Domany-Kinzel model on the honeycomb lattice as bricks. In the current model, we cannot get such lower bound or upper bound uniformly for any {{p}_{1}},\,{{p}_{2}}\in \left[0,1\right) with {{p}_{1}}\vee {{p}_{2}}>0, especially when α is smaller than 1 and very close to 1, while b/|c| is larger than 1 and very close to 1 (i.e. {{p}_{1}}\vee {{p}_{2}} is very close to 1 or {{p}_{1}}\wedge {{p}_{2}} is very close to 0). Notice that the value 13/12 given in case (3) is not optimal and can be improved. The bounds given in (, 2.13: #jstataa4abdeqn017) must be relaxed to be the corresponding bounds given in (, 2.11: #jstataa4abdeqn015) and (, 2.12: #jstataa4abdeqn016), which are valid uniformly for any {{p}_{1}},\,{{p}_{2}}\in \left[0,1\right) with {{p}_{1}}\vee {{p}_{2}}>0

One can consider another version of directed bond percolation on the square lattice such that vertical edges from (m, 2n) to (m, 2n + 1) are directed upward with probability p1 and vertical edges from (m, 2n + 1) to (m, 2n + 2) are directed upward with probability p2 for m,\,n\in {{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}, and horizontal edges are directed rightward with probabilities 1 (see figure, 3: #jstataa4abdf03). This model is much easier and the method of steepest decent can be used to get {{\alpha}_{c}}=\left({{q}_{1}}{{p}_{1}}+{{q}_{2}}{{p}_{2}}\right)/2{{p}_{1}}{{p}_{2}} instantly. Although this model looks similar to the model we consider here, {{\alpha}_{c}} is clearly different
